The Liverpool Chronicle Of Sept. l says the ac-
counts recently received from Portugal are OF ni-

lists may be defeated, unless they at once receive
the most decisive support from England.


Meetings have been held in Birmingham and Liv-

Amonument to Mr. Canning is to be erected at Ilv-

receive moro than one tenth part OF the sum crrone-

The harvest in England has commenced, and the
prospect Of its being abundant was very promising
The defeat of the Russians by the Pcrsans at LII
rvian is confirmed. The Russian Cavalry suffered
severely.


The troubles in Spain continue, and under date Of

der exists in the assembages OF the insurgents The

have their eye OH the fortress of Cardonne, the pos
session ofwhich was so valuable to Nina in 1928
The government, alarmed at the progress OF the IN
surrecton in Catalonia, has given orders to assem-
BILE 5000 men in the province. Trade was com
pleely interrupted at Barcelona by these disturb
ances. The Apostolical party (alias lnqnsitorial
had commenced plundering and leyying contrbu
tions they had twice approached within League
of Barcelona, and some OF the Spanish troops lately
sent against them had joined the standard OF th'
Church as it is termed.


The Greek subsistence committee had at its dis
posal on the first Of June, 9S, 200 Spanish dollars
besides ten ship ads of provisions, which woul
arrive after that date. Howitzers, to be mounte
on mules. with skilful engineer, and the means
making powder, had been sent from Marseilles.


The fall of the Acropolis of Athens is attribute
to the ntrigues oi Austrian agent, aud the tres
cherry of the French Colonel, Fabvier. No impres
sion had been made upon it at the time OF il

A letter from the isle Of Zante, dated the 2nd
August, says. Admiral Cochrane after havil
burnt the Egyptian brig before Alexandria. and ca
Ied terror into the enemy's country has returned
Poros. Yesterday morning little lrisae of
cannons, and schooner of the Turkish feet, pass
our island for the purpose of going to Patros su
denly Admiral Cochrane appeared near Scropl,
with the Hellas and the Soter (Savior) Phlhell
brig about noon IA brisk firing was heard. and
the evening we had news of the battle. This mol
ing, early the lIellas was seen bearing up to
island along with the Softer, which had in II
the enemy's frisate, the Greek flag flying at
mast head. The Turkish crew had been obliged
surrender, after a resisancc of ten minutes. til
vessel having been greatly damaged by the fire
the Heas The Greek sailors were on its de
enleavorng to repair the injuries it had received
The manmast was broken at the place which
ceives it. but it would be easy to mend. i
Greeks came so near to our port that we were alb
with Telescope, TO distinguish the men. As
the Turkish schooner, it was taken without hav
received any injury. The Greek vessel sailed
wards Clarenza. where they will anchor, and ;
the schooner by tomorrow morning.

the fishing privileges within her jurisdiction, which
were secured to us under the treaty of 1885. The
Iintrnaton was met by the American Commissioners,
by the following principle, which they broadly laid
down, in letter signed by their entire number
viz: that from the peculiar nature of the treaty o


1888. as treaty of independence, it had not been
abrogated by the war; that we still enjoyed the


fishing privileges, as part of our national lnde-
pendence, and that no grant from the British 60
vernment was necessary. In pursuance OF this
principle, the American Commissioners on the loth
of November 1914, sent to the British negoclators
the preiet of treaty containing no article OF stpu-
la,ion on the subject. On the 26th of November
the British negociaors returned the proc' with sese
raj alterations. one Of which that British sub
iects should have access to the river Mississippi and
the free navigation ol that river.


10 this the American commissioners could not
in itself object, because it was secured to the Bf
tisl, bv the treaty Of 1888. which the American
Commissioners cuntendeu was not abrosaed by the
war.


In order, however, not to give the British the ad


vantage of any new stipulation, IN the treaty, with


out corresponding advantage to America mrs


fioHatm proposed to admit into the new treaty the


right of the British to navigate the Mississippi, pro


uiscd it were Offset by renewed stipulation OF the
Fishing privileges, in favor of America.
For this proposal MIR. Gallan, (the mover) Mr.


Adams, and Mr. Bayard voted !; against 1t Mr. Clay


and Jonathan Russell. The majority being III favor


Of it, il was offered the British negocators, and by


them rejected on the ground, no doubt, that while


the fisheries were of immense consequence to US.


the right Of navigating the Mississippi was to them


merely nominal.


The treaty of Client was consequently negotiated


without any stipulation on the subject.


i In the cOny ent0n of 8l8 between the U. States
* Great Britain, which was negotiated by Mr. Rusl


under the instruction of MIR. Adams, the entire
fishing interest was satisfactorily adjusted Grea
! Britain stipulated to the enjsyment OF the essen


tal part OF the fishing liberties claimed, and tacitl,


renounced all pretensons to navigate the Missls
. sipp.


Such is the history Of the caumnious insinuaion


that Mr.. Adams proposed to open the navigation q
: the Mississippi to Great Britain.


!. Muy'and.-The election struggle has termina
j., ed, in This State, in the entire discontinue of tn
!, Jackson party. Never were sanguine hope
J. of success entertained by any set of men neve
i were greater efforts made to reduce those hopes
: reality. Yet all has failed The misrepresentation
of the Opposition editors have failed the gratultou

ders, has failed the cry OF prescription has failed


the menace of personal violence has failed the eli
Dorate accusations Drought by the jackson ComD


nation against the Administration has miserablv fii
i ed. Sound views and correct principles have achie
Il ed the redemption of maryland; and she stant
nf forth bright example to Virginia, Pennsylyan
" North Carolina and the other States, in which CO
ID rect principles are now strongly contending for Vi
= tory.

should be accomplished and the effort was in pr

From tie National Ltelfgcnccr.


More than one Of the Combination prints has had
the assurances 10 accuse us ofcalumnatlng Gen. jack
son in the article wherein we referred to several IN
ccnts in his pubic lie going 10 shew, as we thought,
il habit of temper and action Incompatible VITA Inc
highest civil trust and dignity.


The fact Of this accusation shews they are OF the
same onnion as ourselves, that the traits OF charac-
ter there developed arc not such as recommend Gen.
Jackson for the Presidency: fer if they are why DO
they fall into violent passion with us for stating
them? If they reputable TO HIM as public
man if they add any thing TO his just fame, or at
ford any promise Of future eminence, why is 1t es-
teemed calumny in US to develope them?


The only question about these statements. then is
as to their truth: because, if true, they are not cal
umny, but history-and the allegation Of their be-
ing caumny, only proves the irresistbity of the
conclusions which flow from them.


As to their truth, then, we aver that they are IN
disputabe: that there is not word syllable of
them which is not record either in the docu-
ments of the Government in unlisputed news
paper publications. The statement of Mr.. Lacock,
referring to the personal threats Of the General to
cut of the ears ofmembers Of Congress, copied
at the time it made with suitable expression OF
disgust. by the very prints which now head the Par
L ty Combination against the principles which they
once proclaimed from the house-top. The Rich
mond Enquirer only three years ago, being several
years after his defence Of the Committee Of the Sen
ate, pronounced General Lacock to be "a man Of
high character man of truth The Editors Of
the Richmond Enquirer of course believe every
thing that MIR. Lacock stated concerning Gen. Jack
son. Let them come forward, then, and defend the
threat to cut of the OF the Senators, and among
them, those Of Mr.. Eppes, the late distinguished
Senator from Virginia, for vcnturng to question the
public conduct of Gen. Jackson. Let them defend
the other actions quoted by us which they were
among the first and oudest TO condemn. We chal-
enge them any Of their present coopcrators, to


isprovc title Of the article which they pronounce
to be calumnous, md which. 50 far from intending
malice, was written with reluctance with studied for
bearance, and under the Indispensable necessity o
: defending opposition to Gen. Jacksons election
to which have ever had rooted objections, on pub
lie and political grounds solely.

A letter from the isle Of Zante, dated the 2nd
August, says. Admiral Cochrane after havil
burnt the Egyptian brig before Alexandria. and ca
Ied terror into the enemy's country has returned
Poros. Yesterday morning little lrisae of
cannons, and schooner of the Turkish feet, pass
our island for the purpose of going to Patros su
denly Admiral Cochrane appeared near Scropl,
with the Hellas and the Soter (Savior) Phlhell
brig about noon IA brisk firing was heard. and
the evening we had news of the battle. This mol
ing, early the lIellas was seen bearing up to
island along with the Softer, which had in II
the enemy's frisate, the Greek flag flying at
mast head. The Turkish crew had been obliged
surrender, after a resisancc of ten minutes. til
vessel having been greatly damaged by the fire
the Heas The Greek sailors were on its de
enleavorng to repair the injuries it had received
The manmast was broken at the place which
ceives it. but it would be easy to mend. i
Greeks came so near to our port that we were alb
with Telescope, TO distinguish the men. As
the Turkish schooner, it was taken without hav
received any injury. The Greek vessel sailed
wards Clarenza. where they will anchor, and ;
the schooner by tomorrow morning.

yuot intend again 10 grand IA .fhdW an eq'aydle'h
the fishing privileges within her jurisdiction, which
were secured to us under the treaty of 1885. The
Iintrnaton was met by the American Commissioners,
by the following principle, which they broadly laid
down, in letter signed by their entire number
viz: that from the peculiar nature of the treaty o


1888. as treaty of independence, it had not been
abrogated by the war; that we still enjoyed the


fishing privileges, as part of our national lnde-
pendence, and that no grant from the British 60
vernment was necessary. In pursuance OF this
principle, the American Commissioners on the loth
of November 1914, sent to the British negoclators
the preiet of treaty containing no article OF stpu-
la,ion on the subject. On the 26th of November
the British negociaors returned the proc' with sese
raj alterations. one Of which that British sub
iects should have access to the river Mississippi and
the free navigation ol that river.


10 this the American commissioners could not
in itself object, because it was secured to the Bf
tisl, bv the treaty Of 1888. which the American
Commissioners cuntendeu was not abrosaed by the
war.


In order, however, not to give the British the ad


vantage of any new stipulation, IN the treaty, with


out corresponding advantage to America mrs


fioHatm proposed to admit into the new treaty the


right of the British to navigate the Mississippi, pro


uiscd it were Offset by renewed stipulation OF the
Fishing privileges, in favor of America.
For this proposal MIR. Gallan, (the mover) Mr.


Adams, and Mr. Bayard voted !; against 1t Mr. Clay


and Jonathan Russell. The majority being III favor


Of it, il was offered the British negocators, and by


them rejected on the ground, no doubt, that while


the fisheries were of immense consequence to US.


the right Of navigating the Mississippi was to them


merely nominal.


The treaty of Client was consequently negotiated


without any stipulation on the subject.


i In the cOny ent0n of 8l8 between the U. States
* Great Britain, which was negotiated by Mr. Rusl


under the instruction of MIR. Adams, the entire
fishing interest was satisfactorily adjusted Grea
! Britain stipulated to the enjsyment OF the essen


tal part OF the fishing liberties claimed, and tacitl,


renounced all pretensons to navigate the Missls
. sipp.


Such is the history Of the caumnious insinuaion


that Mr.. Adams proposed to open the navigation q
: the Mississippi to Great Britain.

J. of success entertained by any set of men neve

: reality. Yet all has failed The misrepresentation
of the Opposition editors have failed the gratultou
distribution OF the Telegraph, with its prepared sal
ders, has failed the cry OF prescription has failed


the menace of personal violence has failed the eli
Dorate accusations Drought by the jackson ComD


nation against the Administration has miserablv fii
i ed. Sound views and correct principles have achie
Il ed the redemption of maryland; and she stant
nf forth bright example to Virginia, Pennsylyan
" North Carolina and the other States, in which CO
ID rect principles are now strongly contending for Vi
= tory.

1 of the Administration and the political existence

full articles.article:
From tie National Ltelfgcnccr.


More than one Of the Combination prints has had
the assurances 10 accuse us ofcalumnatlng Gen. jack
son in the article wherein we referred to several IN
ccnts in his pubic lie going 10 shew, as we thought,
il habit of temper and action Incompatible VITA Inc
highest civil trust and dignity.


The fact Of this accusation shews they are OF the
same onnion as ourselves, that the traits OF charac-
ter there developed arc not such as recommend Gen.
Jackson for the Presidency: fer if they are why DO
they fall into violent passion with us for stating
them? If they reputable TO HIM as public
man if they add any thing TO his just fame, or at
ford any promise Of future eminence, why is 1t es-
teemed calumny in US to develope them?


The only question about these statements. then is
as to their truth: because, if true, they are not cal
umny, but history-and the allegation Of their be-
ing caumny, only proves the irresistbity of the
conclusions which flow from them.


As to their truth, then, we aver that they are IN
disputabe: that there is not word syllable of
them which is not record either in the docu-
ments of the Government in unlisputed news
paper publications. The statement of Mr.. Lacock,
referring to the personal threats Of the General to
cut of the ears ofmembers Of Congress, copied
at the time it made with suitable expression OF
disgust. by the very prints which now head the Par
L ty Combination against the principles which they
once proclaimed from the house-top. The Rich
mond Enquirer only three years ago, being several
years after his defence Of the Committee Of the Sen
ate, pronounced General Lacock to be "a man Of
high character man of truth The Editors Of
the Richmond Enquirer of course believe every
thing that MIR. Lacock stated concerning Gen. Jack
son. Let them come forward, then, and defend the
threat to cut of the OF the Senators, and among
them, those Of Mr.. Eppes, the late distinguished
Senator from Virginia, for vcnturng to question the
public conduct of Gen. Jackson. Let them defend
the other actions quoted by us which they were
among the first and oudest TO condemn. We chal-
enge them any Of their present coopcrators, to


isprovc title Of the article which they pronounce
to be calumnous, md which. 50 far from intending
malice, was written with reluctance with studied for
bearance, and under the Indispensable necessity o
: defending opposition to Gen. Jacksons election
to which have ever had rooted objections, on pub
lie and political grounds solely.

5 degree of talents 1t is to be devoted to Interna

ter into the endless cavils and snuosites of pot

IS ''It has been repeatedly asserted and as ofte


contradcted, that changes in favor of the presen


Administration of the general government have tax


EN- place III the interior OF our state A recent t0u


through all the principal and most populuus countie


in the state, gave US an opportunity Of ascerainin


the truth or faalty OF these reports. This oppo


tunty was improved by inquiry made in wa


calculated tn elicit truth without the possibilit


of bias and we are enabled to state that in ever


county and in every town through which we passet


from Philadelphia to the western extremity OF ii


state, changes in favor of the Administrations ha,


taken place, and IN many districts to very consid


rable extent.''
